Introduction

Osteosarcoma is derived from osteoid-forming mesenchymal cells and is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and young adults.  This aggressive tumor typically occurs in the metaphysis of long bones (eg, distal femur, proximal tibia) (

figure 1
).

Pathogenesis

Osteosarcoma is thought to arise in mesenchymal stem cells or osteoblastic progenitor cells due to a multifactorial involvement of tumor suppressor gene deregulation, oncogene activation, and a lack of DNA repair mechanisms.  This malignant transformation occurs mostly during the rapid growth phase of long bones (ie, adolescence) but can also be due to hereditary genetic mutations (eg, RB1, TP53).  As a result, the affected bone loses its normal trabecular pattern, and disorganized osteoid matrix is deposited by malignant cells.

Risk factors

Risk factors for the development of osteosarcoma include the following:

  • Age:  Osteosarcoma has a bimodal distribution in children and adolescents age <25 (peak age 13-18, during times of rapid growth) and adults age >50.
  • Genetic mutations involving tumor suppressor genes:
    • RB1 encodes for RB, a protein that regulates cell-cycle progression.  Inactivating RB1 mutations promotes unchecked and unregulated cellular replication and is commonly associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma.
    • TP53 encodes for P53, a protein that maintains genomic integrity by facilitating DNA repair.  Germ-line TP53 mutations are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which increases the risk for multiple tumors, including osteosarcoma.
  • Paget disease of the bone:  The associated bone remodeling and overgrowth increase the risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in older patients.
  • Prior cancer treatment:  Chemotherapy and radiation therapy damages bone, increasing cellular turnover and the risk of osteosarcoma.

Clinical presentation

Patients with osteosarcoma are most commonly adolescents or adults age >50 with localized pain that is dull and progressive over weeks.  Increased physical activity, minor trauma, or pathologic fracture may incidentally call attention to the lesion.

The most common sites of tumor development are the metaphyses of long bones (eg, distal femur, proximal tibia), the region adjacent to the growth plate where bone proliferation is the greatest.  Other bones, such as the skull or pelvis, are rarely affected.

Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss) are usually absent but may indicate advanced disease.

Examination shows tenderness and swelling, often with a palpable soft tissue mass.  Depending on the location and extent of joint involvement, patients may demonstrate decreased range of motion or an abnormal gait.

Evaluation

The initial step in evaluation is imaging, typically x-ray then MRI.

  • X-ray shows the following (
    image 1
    ):
    • Ill-defined, osteolytic/osteoblastic lesion, seen as irregular radiolucent (bone destruction) and radiodense (bone formation) areas within the metaphysis of a long bone.
    • "Sunburst" periosteal reaction (
      image 2
      ), an aggressive periosteal reaction characterized by ossification of fragmented fibers perpendicular to the bone.  Other nonspecific, aggressive periosteal reactions (eg, Codman triangle) suggestive of rapid tumor growth can also occur.
  • MRI is performed after x-ray to evaluate tumor extension into the bone, growth plate, and/or soft tissue (eg, nerves, blood vessels).  MRI is also critical for surgical planning because it can identify necrotic or hypervascular areas that should be avoided.

Laboratory evaluation may reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase levels from osteoid formation and turnover of damaged osteocytes.  Complete blood count and inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) are usually normal unless metastatic or systemic involvement occurs.

Diagnosis

Biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis, and histologic findings include malignant cells resembling osteoblasts of varying size (pleomorphic) with atypical nuclei and irregular, lace-like osteoid (ie, unmineralized bone matrix composed of type I collagen) (

image 3
).

Differential diagnosis

  • Ewing sarcoma:  The second-most common primary bone malignancy in children and adolescents.  It often arises in the diaphysis of long bones, causing progressive pain and swelling.  Systemic findings (eg, fever, leukocytosis) are common.  X-ray shows a lytic lesion surrounded by a lamellated periosteal reaction (ie, "onion skinning") (
    image 4
    ).  Biopsy demonstrates sheets of uniform, round tumor cells (
    image 5
    ).
  • Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor of bone):  A benign but locally aggressive tumor in long-bone epiphyses that causes chronic, localized pain.  Imaging reveals a "soap bubble" appearance due to bony trabeculae within the lesion (
    image 6
    ).
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis:  A rare, malignant histiocytic disorder that can affect multiple organ systems (eg, bone, skin, lungs), most often seen in children age <3.  Single or multiple "punched-out," lytic bone lesions are seen on x-ray (
    image 7
    ).
  • Osteoid osteoma:  A small, benign, bone-forming tumor that typically occurs in the lower extremity of adolescents.  It causes pain that is characteristically worse at night and relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  X-ray reveals a well-circumscribed, round radiolucent nidus with surrounding sclerosis (
    image 8
    ).
  • Stress fracture:  An overuse injury to bone caused by repetitive stress (eg, running on pavement) that presents with an insidious onset of localized pain that is worse with activity.  X-ray may show a fracture line (
    image 9
    ), periosteal elevation, or cortical thickening, depending on the age of the lesion.
  • Osteomyelitis:  Bacterial bone infection that causes progressive pain, limited mobility, and signs of systemic inflammation (eg, fever, leukocytosis).  X-ray often reveals an ill-defined lytic lesion (without osteoblastic areas) and a surrounding periosteal reaction (
    image 10
    ).

Management

Bone scintigraphy, CT, or positron emission tomography (PET) is used for staging and locating metastatic disease.  Staging is categorized as either localized (primary bone Â± surrounding tissue only) or metastatic (lymph node or systemic; most commonly lung or other bone).

Treatment typically includes systemic chemotherapy and limb-sparing surgery when possible.

Prognosis

The survival rate for localized disease is favorable with prompt treatment.  Poor prognostic factors include metastases at diagnosis, primary nonâ€“long-bone tumor (eg, axial skeleton), and age >40.

Summary

Osteosarcoma (
